segments.text: I set up a consultant service, labor consultant, and went to the steamship companies and got them to retain me.
I was just getting going good when the
government took over their ships.
And this was in 1941, and Joe Curran asked me to come to Washington as the legislative representative for the unions, maritime unions of the CIO, CIO Maritime Committee.
So that's what I did.
I came to Washington then.
So he appointed you after he had become a vice president of the CIO?
Yeah, he was the vice president of the CIO then, but he didn't appoint me as vice president of the CIO.
He appointed me as chairman of the CIO Maritime Committee.
So I came to Washington, and that's my life.
spent the rest of my life in Washington.
I stayed with the CIO Maritime Committee, and in 1950, I guess it was, I set up what was known as the Labor Management Maritime Committee, because I realized that unless we can get the
industry working together, that is, labor and management.
We were never going to get anywhere.
So I set up that committee, and that's why you see it here on the present time, I think.
And then, of course, I retired.
And I'm busier now than I was before I retired.
Did you know a Jerry King?
Jerry King?
Yes.
Knew him quite well.
Uh, what do you think his stand was?
His stand was?
What faction did he fit into?
He fitted into the shipowner faction.
Any particular shipowning company that might have controlled him, in your opinion?
Uh, I don't know which one, but I do know that he was controlled by the ship companies.
When I was told that, I said I don't want to know any of the details.
If I know any of the details, I'll go tell the NMU.
So don't tell me.
So did you have any recollections on the Mariners Club?
Not really, except they were trying to take over control of the Union and really put it under the control of the companies.
During the war years, you spent your time here in Washington.
Yeah.
During this time, in your opinion, did the relationship of the government toward the Union, or the opinion of the government toward the NMU, change any?
Oh, yes.
Can you date that to any particular time, or what do you think it was, how would you describe it before the war started and then during and after?
I would say from the time that the government took over the ships their attitude towards the Union started to change because they found that the Union was more cooperative than ship owners.
Why do you think this was?
Why the Union all of a sudden become cooperative?
Well, I think it was because the companies were interested in the money angle and not so much in the war angle and the Union was more interested in the
war angle.
The Union was interested in protecting the ships and winning the war.
What do you think Admiral Emery Lanz, what was his opinion of the NMU and of Joe Kern?
Well, I would say that Emery Lanz, like most of the
military men at that time were anti-union.
But he was smart enough to recognize that he was going to have to have the help of the Union if he was going to do his job.
So, while he didn't buy everything that they said, he did cooperate with them and seek their cooperation.
And he wouldn't hesitate to
to read the right act of them just like he would read the right act of the president if the occasion presented itself.
What about...
He was a strong personality, no question about it, and to show his interest in the seamen during the war, seamen were not permitted in the clubs of USO and
He was trying to find a way to solve that.
So his wife suggested to him that maybe they ought to set up their own clubs for the seamen.
He said, that's a great idea.
I'll take it to the president.
He took it to the president.
The president said, I'm all in favor of it.
But don't let it be a government organization.
Have it a private organization.
Because if it's not a private organization, it'll never accomplish its purpose.
If it's a government organization, it won't.
Were you active in presenting the unions side at the December 19, 1941 meeting between the ship owners, the at that time Maritime Commission, and the labor unions and the statement of principles?
Yes, I was.
And what was your input into that?
Well, I wrote the final statement.
Why wasn't the union's original proposals for a tripartite board acceptable instead of the mediating board that came out?
Why wasn't the NMU able to get this point of view accepted?

I don't remember the details, but I can tell you at the time, and not just at that time, but ever since, it has been my opinion that government is about the worst thing that can happen to any industry, labor or management.
Their intervention into
Business world or labor world is the worst thing that can happen for the business or the union or the country.
And if you look at where we are now, you'll find that the intervention of government is what has put us where we are today.
If we had a government all formed by the people, fine.
But we don't.
We have a government all formed by the banking industry.
They control the banks.
They nominate the president.
They elect the president.
They tell the president what to do.
And most congressmen, they don't tell what to do.
They do it without being told.
What was your relationship with the WSA, the warship administration?
Well, I was on the Marine panel.
And I was active in lobbying.
the war shipping panel itself, and I was very active with Senator Truman and his committee.
I forget the name of the committee.
War Production Committee.
I don't remember now, but he was, he headed up a committee that was the most influential committee on war matters and on shipping matters at the time.
And I was very active, of course, with the staff of that committee.
I was a lobbyist.
I tried to do my job.
What about your relationship and the union's relationship with the RMO, Recruitment and Manning?
The Recruitment and Manning Organization, RMO.
I don't remember it.
It was headed by McCauley?
Who?
McCauley.
Captain McCullen?
Oh, he was one of the commissioners.
In particular, what I'm getting at is the agreement that was reached in 42.

Well, first of all, the talk of the Merchant Marine being nationalized and placed under the Navy, and then the subsequent agreements that come out between Lundberg and the WSA, and then later on the NMU and their relationship, their agreement with Admiral Land.
I don't remember much of the details, but I do remember McCauley and we being very close.
We felt that McCauley was the one commissioner at that time who we could rely upon to be fair.
During the war time, was there any fear by the NMU that the government and or the operators were attempting in some way to destroy the hiring hall?
Oh, yes.
And if so, what would the union have been prepared to do?
More or less, would they have, or did Cheran and the NMU ever consider the possibility of dropping the no-strike pledge?
If they had gotten down to really destroying the Union Hall, there would have been a strike threat.
There would have been a strike, not just a strike threat.
There would have been a strike.
No question about it.
Had there ever been any, were there ever any contingency plans made by the Union for a strike during?
No.
Would you consider this then a type of act of faith as far as the Union goes in unilaterally declaring this no-strike pledge the day after Pearl Harbor?
Was this tactically done by Curran, or was it strictly good faith, or was he hoping for something down the road to come out of this?
Or was it just a pure act of patriotism?
Well, he...
The Union was 100% for winning the war, so the Union was all behind all efforts to win that war, no question about it.
Up to but not including losing the hiring hall.
Well, this is pure guesswork on my part, but I don't think they would have permitted the hiring hall to be destroyed.
because they knew if that were destroyed, they wouldn't have a Union after the war.
Who was influential in talking Joe into shipping out his Navy during the war to check the seamen's conditions abroad?
Nobody.
That was just his own?
That was his own idea.
He wanted to find out what could be done
to improve the war effort.
And that's what he wanted to do.
He wanted to go see firsthand what was happening then.
The Union begins developing a post-war program around 1943.
How much input did you have into this?
Probably all of it.
Would you like to go into more detail?
Well,
No one in the NMU was thinking of anything after the war.
As a matter of fact, there literally has never been any planning in the NMU.
It went along from day to day.
And I told Joe, there's about time we started to think of some of those things.
About when was it approximately?
I'd say probably about 43 or somewhere in there.
So I got to talking about it, and Harry Bridges happened to come to town while Joe happened to be in town.
I forget what it may have been, a committee meeting.
I don't know.
And I told him some of my ideas, some of the things that I thought we ought to be talking about.
And I said, for example, I think one of the most important things that could be done right now in terms of
war has nothing to do with the future, but actually winning the war is containerization.
So we got to talking about that, and Harry was interested, and he said, will you prepare me a paper on it?
So I prepared him a paper, and that was the beginning of the container ships, really.
And I went to

First time I was in New York, I went to see Franklin, who was United States lines, and Emmett McCormick of more McCormick lines, and told them that I thought they ought to be thinking in terms of building container ships, because this is where cargo is going to end up in the commerce of the world.
Neither one of them could see it.
No business.
And then when I developed the program, I told them that the...
I went back to these same two guys in connection with one thing, and that was the, you know, shipping after the war.
Because this time I was working on, you know, what the program was going to be like after the war.
And I got into...
whole question of how many ships we were going to have, and that meant bottom dropping out of shipping as far as companies and unions were concerned.
And Joe wouldn't believe me at all.
He said, it just isn't going to happen.
We're going to continue having a good merchant marine.
And I depicted a cut in ships.
I said, you've got to think of other things.
Well, before I get to that, I started to tell about this
these two guys, two main guys really in shipping at that time.
And I suggested to them that in addition, I said, you couldn't see light on this question of container ships.
But I said, the big need for the United States after the war is going to be bulk ships.
tankers and ore carriers.
I said, why don't you give some thought to investing money in either one of these?
Because there's money to be made in it.
So they said, well, now, bulk carriers is an idea.
Let's explore that.
What's your idea on the bulk carriers?
So I told them the kind of ships I was thinking of, 100,000 ton ships.
never heard of, you know.
You were talking the big ships at that time was 15,000 tons.
That was a big ship.
They couldn't see ships of that size.
I said, well, you go talk to the people that have to import this ore, and see what they think of it.
And then I projected to them my idea of where we were headed, both in terms of petroleum and
ore products.
And I told them that our supplies in the United States just weren't going to be adequate.
I said, by the year 2000, we'll be importing at least eighty to ninety percent of ore and oil.
And this they couldn't see.
None of these people had any visions at all.
I don't understand why they couldn't see what was happening.
But I said, well, I don't have the statistics on this, but I'm going to get them.
I'll get them together, and I'll show them to you.

And I said, you just have to realize that with the kind of economy that we have and the growth that is essential to meet the minimum employment needs of this nation are just going to have to skyrocket.
You just won't be able to believe it.
But they said, well, I've
How in the world do you think we can get in the ore trade?
I said, first of all, you have to get off your ass and stop thinking of subsidies.
Because at one time or another, the government's going to cut out these subsidies, and they ought to cut them out.
The only reason for a subsidy, really, is for national defense and for protecting our commerce.
Have enough ships to
protect their commerce against high rates from foreign ships.
That's the only two reasons you can give for it, and you know it.
I said, this business of living off of Uncle Sam is just a lazy man's way, and you ought to start using your head on these things.
I said, if I were a ship owner, I would go to U.S. Steel, I would go to American Aluminum, and organizations like this that are going to be importing bulk ores, and I would go to
Companies like Standard Oil of New Jersey, Shell, who charter at least half of their ships and work out some deals with them.
Well, that sounds like a good idea.
Never got off the ground, but it was a good idea.
But really, the shipping industry in the United States was, you know,
built on subsidies.
That's all they could think of.
You can't compete with foreigners.
And I kept telling them they were crazy.
They just had to get more production.
You had to get bigger ships, like any other industry.
If you're going to create wealth, you've got to create production.
If you're going to create production, you've got to have labor interchange.
The whole system is built on interchange of labor.
It started off with the shoemaker making shoes for the hat maker, and the hat maker hats for the shoemakers, and the baker, baker for both of them.
And that's the way it started off.
But you're not living in that kind of economy anymore.
You're living in a very fast-growing economy that's going to be monetized, and you have to be thinking in those terms.
And I said, the people who are going to be successful are going to be the people who design and operate the most efficient ships.
And the most efficient ships is going to be a ship that's going to carry 10 times as much cargo as you carry now with the same crew or maybe even less crew.
I said, for example, you know you can operate a ship without any crew on it at all.
But think in terms of it as the same crew for the larger ship.
Well, they thought on it, but never did anything about it.
Other entrepreneurs came along and did the job for them.
But specifically for the NMU, I showed them what their membership was going to shrink from.
I forget what it was right after the war.
It seems to me it was about 125,000 members.
And I told them that that job program would probably shrink to deep sea
of between 10 and 20,000 people.
I said, you just have to think in those terms.
That means you've got to get out and organize other people.
The natural thing that I think you should do is to organize the people who work in the steamship companies.
That's a natural for you.
Then I gave them a few other ideas of associated industries that would seem to make some sense.
to people that I knew were absolutely opposed to anything except semen in their union.
Was Karen receptor to the United?
He was not.
Absolutely not.
Nothing but semen in his union.
And he went on like that almost till the end.
And it was just sheer necessity of staying alive that finally convinced him that he had to do something else.
And then they started organizing other people.
Who was the driving force behind developing the PAC movement during the war, the Political Action Committee?
Whose brainchild was that?
Oh, what's his name?
head of the garment workers, Goldman.
Lewis, was it Lewis Goldman?
Well, specifically in the NMU, who was receptive to the idea?
I'm not really sure.
I think it was really an outgrowth of what was happening.
I think we all realized that the Washington scene had to be covered.
That there were about, as I recall, 23 agencies in Washington who had something to do with the maritime industry.
And I don't think this was anyone's idea specifically that
you know, of coming forth with the idea that this had to be done.
I think it was just a natural outgrowth of the fact that we were dealing with these things all the time and this had to be done.
And I know that this idea finally took head.
The NMU was the first one to put someone down here.
I don't remember what his name was now, but they had a representative down here.
before, I think, even before the CIO was formed.
But when the CIO was formed, Joe suggested that everyone get together and set up this committee and have representation here at the Washington level, and that's what was done.
That was when the CIO Maritime Committee was set up.
So I don't think it was anyone's idea as such, just the need was there and had to be met.
Was this acceptable also to the left-wing or the communist factions?
Yes, it was.
They understood the need also?
Yeah.
Probably, if you take it back, the Copland book was probably the bellwether of the whole thing.
I'm really not sure.
I don't remember anyone coming up with the idea that, you know, we've got to have representation in Washington.
I think everyone knew we had to have representation in Washington because of the situation that existed.
Going back to the Curran-Bridges relationship, it seems to me that we even put in the NMU Constitution representation in Washington.
I think we did, as a matter of fact.
But you know, we'd been through the NRA already, and all of Roosevelt's so-called recovery programs by then.
As far as Curran and Bridges goes, and their relationship, could you pick up on that particularly, say, from the beginning of the war on?
Their relationship was purely a relationship of mutual help for each other's union.
Neither one of them really had any use for the other one.
Personally, I'm talking on a personal basis now.
But they both recognized that they needed help from each other.
And to get help from each other, they ought to help each other.
And it was just, again, the awareness of the
of the needs.

Who was the person within the NMU then that started the idea of the Union backing Bridges so strongly in his deportation hearings, particularly in 39 and the deportation hearings in 42, to the point where they issued fighting stamps?
I think this was an ILA program that was started on the West Coast and got the support of the
And Bridges brought it to the CIO Maritime Committee, too, of course.
And there just wasn't any question.
There was, at that time, in the movement, there was never any question but what one union was going to support the other maritime union.
On any issue.
Didn't make any difference what the issue was.
They just supported it.
If one union put up a picket line, another one is not going to touch it.
There was just that much solidarity and that much understanding of the need to help each other at that time.
Even if it meant crossing ideological boundaries?
Well, I think each one of these,

had their ideological reasons also, because they were, if you're building a base, you know, for your party guys on anything you do, if you're strengthening the organization, you're building a party base.
I can remember a meeting that we had here in Washington
where we were talking about the 40-hour week.
This grew out of my suggestion to the seamen that they ought to start thinking in terms of more employment aboard the ships.
When would this be, after the war?
Beg your pardon?
When would this be?
This was after the war.
It may have not been after the war.
It may have been just before the war ended.
I'm not just sure of the timing on it.
But anyway, I came up with the idea that we ought to think in terms of putting more people on the ship.
And doing this, think of a 40-hour week.
And I was thinking purely of the employment situation, because it was perfectly obvious to me that we were going to have a tremendous drop in the employment of merchant seamen.
I guess this would have had to have been after the general who became Secretary of State, Marshall, after the Marshall Plan.
It became perfectly obvious to me that we were going to not only rebuild the European allies
industries, but we were going to rebuild their merchant marines, too.
If we rebuild their merchant marine, that meant that our shipping was going to drop down from about sixty percent to, I was figuring ten percent as the lowest, but of course it didn't hold there.
Do you remember Joe's pamphlet, Porkchops and Politics?
Did he write that, or was it ghostwritten?
Joe wrote everything that his name was on.
Well, I'll take that back now.
There's some of these books that were written that his name was put on them.
But for example, his column in the paper, he literally wrote every one of those himself.
And the pork chops thing, I'm sure he wrote too.
But it was edited, of course, after he wrote it.
And his column was frequently edited.
Not all the time, but frequently edited.
If he had a good editor, it was edited.
If he didn't have a good editor, it wasn't edited.
I know when Bernie Raskin was editor, he edited all of Joe's columns.
So I don't remember the details on pork chops, but I feel sure it was edited, but I also feel sure that Joe wrote it.
Joe grew in the job.
be a very capable person.
I would say really that there were, and this is definitely off the record.
Concerning the development during the war of the Committee for Maritime Unity, what was your stand as far as this goes and the NMU?
I think at that time the only role I had in it was as a functionary trying to come up with ideas and ways to try to bring it forward and to make it work.
I think originally I told Joe that I never had any hopes for it.
I told him, I said, I think you are just barking up the tree if you think you'll ever get Lundberg, really.
to honestly participate in maritime unity where you or Bridges are concerned.
As far as this maritime committee, unity committee goes, when or how was it that Joe began to perceive that he and Bridges were coming to a loggerhead?
Was this, again, an ego clash, or was there something else that started to put the wedge between Kieran and Bridges?
Because apparently they had a very close, at least working, relationship for quite a while.
Yes, they did have a close relationship.
I think the thing that did that was a fellow with the name of Goldblatt, who became secretary-treasurer of the ILWU and became a...
What do you call it?
Well, he was looking for Bridges' job.
And I think that he drove a wedge between Bridges and Curran.
I think that's, that's the really where this started.
He also was a party functionary.
not just a member, he was a party functionary.
I don't know what function he had now, I don't remember.

But he perceived Joe as being too strong a person for the party to take on, and him personally to take on, and he couldn't perceive of anyone in the maritime industry being more important than he was.
And this was another case of a
a person of small stature not being able to work with someone, physically I'm talking about, physically larger stature.
And that literally was that he was that kind of a person.
When was it that Joe began to perceive that he was going to have to have some type of a clash with the communist elements within the Union?
And I'm trying to think of the incident.
There was something.
I know what it was, the Standard Oil strike.
This was the key to that.
It was early as 39.
Yeah, that was the key to it.
You think had there been no World War II that there might have been a clash earlier in 45?
Probably.
probably.
But the war set that aside, because he finally perceived, recognized that this was a hell of a mistake that he let the muckery into.
Why did the, during this time then, did Joe allow the press to continue branding him as a communist?
Well, how was he going to
keep from being branded.
They branded me as a communist, too.
So he had no input or no inside contacts with the press, did he?
Sure you have any contacts, but those contacts don't control the policy of the press, just like they don't control it today.
The powers that run the country control the press, and they'll print what they want to print.
For example, you don't find them printing that the Federal Reserve steals the money from the people of the United States, do you?
You don't find them printing that the activities of the Federal Reserve cause the depressions and the unemployment?
They're responsible for the inflation.
You don't find that in the press.
When Curran finally decided that he had to take on the Communist elements, was this a personal decision, or did he have other people counseling him?
And if so, when did he start to work out a strategy?
Well, all along the line, he had a strategy to not let the Communist Party program
become a program of the Union.
As I've mentioned earlier, the program was to serve the Union, serve the members, and not the Communist Party.
Now, as long as the Communist Party was willing to work for those programs which served the Union and let that serve themselves, there was no problem.
It's only when you come to a point where their activities were inimical to the best interest of the membership of the Union.
When do you think, then, that the working relationship between Kirillin and the communists began to break down?
There was some incident just before this
convention that you referred to, and Joe asked me if I would go to the Communist Party leadership and explain to them what I perceived the Communists were trying to do to the Union.
And this was after Lannan, you mentioned Lannan, Al Lannan,
That's after he became the chief waterfront guy.

So I had, I went, literally went down to the communist headquarters, I think they were on 14th Street, I'm not sure now, and talked with someone there that I had known previously, a woman, I don't remember her name.
She was a big wig in the party.
and told her and another guy who was also big with what was going on in the Union.
These guys were really trying to control the Union for their own personal interest as well as for the party's interest and not the seamen's interest.
Of course, I recognized their goal was pure party.
But I told her, I said, they're not going to control it.
That way, if they're going to part with Joe on the issue of doing what's best for the seamen, they're going to lose.
And you'd better make up your mind to this.
But I don't remember now what the issues were, but this happened.
And this is while I was working with Standard Oil of New Jersey.
So it was before I came to Washington.
Anyway, the party said, well, now who we're going to believe?
Our, uh, Lannan and Blackie Mars and Jack Lawrence and so on and so on tell us this, and you and Joe telling us something else.
Well, I said, uh, Joe doesn't want a fight with the Communist Party because he thinks it will hurt the Union.
And if it hurts the Union, it's going to
hurt the seamen.
And that's the primary thing he's interested in.
That's the primary thing the Union's interested in, the only thing the Union is interested in.
He said, now, if you want to try to control the Union for the interests of the Communist Party, in the face of that, that's your decision to make.
And they said, well, we'll discuss it with them some more.
But I want to tell you frankly, Hoyt, that we have no hopes of changing the situation.
So they wanted the party's leaders wanted to continue to...
They wanted the party at that point to take over the Union, I think.
This would have been...
I'm not sure of the year.
During the war?
Beg your pardon?
During the war?
Yes, it would have to be...
I just don't remember.
This may have been after the war.
I really don't remember.
Was there anybody... No, this would have had to have been during the war, definitely during the war.
Was there anybody advising Kieran to begin purging the communists?
Well, he was always being advised to do this.
Anybody specifically, beside yourself?
No, I didn't advise him to purge, no.
No, I didn't advise him to purge.
Matter of fact, I didn't think he could.
Was there anybody inside the government who might have been... Not that I know of.
Not that I know of.
I don't think anyone was really advising him to purge the Union.
I know that people were from time to time, as they did with me, raised the question of when is he going to get rid of that...
communist control in the Union.
I said, well, how would you, wouldn't anyone raise it with me?
I'd ask them, how would you go about it?
I said, I've thought of this many times.
And I've always come to the conclusion that I didn't think he could do it.
And I didn't because there were more of them than there were of him.
And I would say that 90% of the officers of the Union were communists.
I know at one time that all of the officers of the national office were communists except Joe, and certainly most of the port agents.
So in your opinion then, when the showdown began in 1945, it was the communists felt that they were strong enough to purge Joe and not vice versa?
That's right.
So they made the first move, not Joe?
They made the first move.
And he acted defensively then?
That's right.
That started out trying to build himself up in the Union without giving Bridges any idea that he was going to replace Bridges.
And I think he simply perceived that one of the ways to do this was to create a real split between Curran and Bridges.
